string.text: This jacket consists of a black leather anorak with Kevlar patches sewn into it. Typically, it is also worn with a backpack made of hemp with extra straps across the chest, blue tracksuit trousers, white running shoes, and a beige hoodie worn underneath.

A regular black leather trench coat. It has no special purpose other than to keep the wearer warm at night or protect them from a blind dog bite. Although the trench coat is not particularly comfortable, it is often used by bandits in the Zone, either because it allows them to hide in the dark, or simply due to its 'cool' appearance.

The outfit of choice for the majority of mercenaries in the Zone, recently 'liberated' by bandits. This variation suffers from external damage, reducing the amount of protection across the board; however, whilst it is not only less costly, it is much easier to get a hold of.

A stalker bodysuit worn by some experienced bandits. The suit is almost identical to a Sunrise as these are most likely taken from captured or killed stalkers. It has been repainted with darker colours and uses a different vest. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

This outfit comprises the military PS5 series body armour with beryllium coating modified for use in the Zone. Originally designed for the military for operations in highly radioactive areas, it has been captured and modified by bandits in the Zone, greatly improving anomaly protection. Comes with an artefact container.

A regular trench coat that hides a stalker bodysuit underneath it. Said bodysuit comes with reinforced body armour made by bandit craftsmen providing good protection against anomalies. The suit cannot be modified with an artefact container, but may be upgraded with a combat support system instead.

The most basic body armour worn by the Clear Sky faction providing good protection from anomalous exposure, its design is reminiscent of the popular Sunrise suit. Includes a container capable of holding one artefact.
The CS-1b is a heavier variant of the CS-1a body armour and consists of a military bulletproof vest with an additional load-bearing vest worn over the top. Comes with a built-in artefact container.
This body armour is often used for conducting search operations in areas of low anomalous activity and as such is a notable improvement over the CS-1. Comes with a built-in artefact container.
The CS-3a consists of a military bulletproof vest. The armour is capable of stopping a pistol bullet, while the wearer is also well protected from anomalies. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

The CS-3b body armour is a suit originally designed by Clear Sky for combat during the faction wars, but has long since been re-purposed. The majority of its bulk comes from the materials made to shield the wearer against any bullets, and its protection against anomalies is likewise sturdy. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

A Clear Sky-branded Sunrise bodysuit, most commonly found among members of the faction who had already possessed unmodified Sunrise bodysuits at the start of their membership. As with regular Sunrise suits, the Clear Sky Sunrise suit features little protection against bullets, but has proven to be popular due to its low cost and potential for modification. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

This suit, produced by one of Kiev's Defence Research Institutes, is a great alternative to home-made stalker suits. It has been adopted by Clear Sky and repainted in the faction's primary colours. While its built-in body armour can only stop light rounds, the anomaly and radiation protection system is second to none. Fully upgradeable and boasting two built-in artefact containers, this bodysuit is the equipment of choice for many experienced stalkers.

This modern version of the Duty bodysuit is better suited for stalkers who are used to or prefer lightweight suits. Unlike the PSZ series, this suit also provides good protection against anomalies. The suit cannot be modified with an artefact container, but may be upgraded with a combat support system instead.

This early model of the Duty bodysuit is based on the Spetsnaz PSZ-9 body armour and modified for used in the Zone. The suit is capable of stopping a rifle bullet, however this level of protection comes at the cost of its weight, bulkiness and virtually non-existent anomaly protection. The suit cannot be modified with an artefact container, but may be upgraded with a combat support system.

A wonderful protective suit for the Zone, mostly appreciated because it combines excellent anomaly with good bullet-proofing qualities. It includes a modified PS5-M suit, a closed cycle breathing system and an integrated system of anomalous field suppression. Unlike other duty outfits, it comes with two artefact containers.

A suit of armour specifically made to withstand radiation hazards. It is composed of three elements: a reinforced jumpsuit, a heavy armoured vest, and a tactical helmet. The vest consists of several thick layers of Kevlar and can be reinforced with composite or titanium plates for increased protection. Does not come with a built-in artefact container.

The SSP-99 chemical protection suit is specially designed by the Ecologists for use in the Zone. It features an integrated air-filtering and air-conditioning system. It is also heat and electricity resistant, and provides good protection against radiation and chemically aggressive environments. It is not designed for combat, so it provides little bullet and splinter protection. Comes with two artefact containers.

The SSP-99M is a high quality variant of the standard SSP-99 Ecologist suit, providing increased defence against bullet and splinter damage, being designed for guards working with scientific expeditions. Comes with two artefact containers.

The Ecologist guard suit is a light bodysuit of twin-layered rubberised cloth with Plexiglas lining and built-in body armour. This suit is modelled after the popular Sunrise suit often worn by stalkers throughout the Zone. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

The Ecologist NBC suit is an advanced version of the Ecologist guard suit. It comes with a GP-5 gas mask using a hose leading to a modern filter, in addition to improved sealing against electric hazards and extra carrying capacity.

The fabric of the Wind of Freedom bodysuit is treated with 'Horizon', a special solution developed by Freedom through trial and error to increase resistance to anomalies. Like the Sunrise suit, the Wind of Freedom comes with built-in body armour and an artefact container.

A modern Freedom model, more suitable to new stalker recruits who are used to simpler suits. Unlike its counterpart, the Wind of Freedom, this variation provides decent protection from anomalies and bullets at the cost of higher weight. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

This stalker bodysuit with reinforced body armour made by Freedom craftsmen represents a good compromise between combat and anomaly protection. The built-in body armour comprises armour plating and ten Kevlar layers capable of stopping a pistol bullet, along with the relatively expensive Sovereign compound for anomaly protection. Comes with an artefact container.

Produced by Freedom specially for research in the Zone. The closed system of breathing and special treatment materials provide excellent protection against harmful radiation and anomalous effects. However, the built-in body armour is not the best, and can break somewhat easily, so it is unsuitable for active hostilities. Fully upgradeable and boasting two built-in artefact containers.

A suit of armour specifically made to withstand radiation hazards. It is composed of three elements: a reinforced jumpsuit, a heavy armoured vest, and a tactical helmet. The vest consists of several thick layers of Kevlar and can be reinforced with composite or titanium plates for increased protection. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

This bodysuit is a combination of a bodysuit of twin-layered rubberised cloth with Plexiglas lining and built-in body armour. Created specifically for members of the now defunct United Nations International Scientific Group, this suit is modelled after the popular Sunrise suit. Comes with built-in artefact containers.

A suit once worn by brave ISG scientists who foraged into Zone's most anomalous areas. It provides good protection from bullet and shrapnel hit, but not enough for large-scale hostilities. Fully upgradeable and boasting two built-in artefact containers.

Outfit of choice for the Mercenary faction. Its design is based on the suit used by the special forces of Western armies. Thanks to a special treatment of the fabric, the armour has a strengthened stability during the physical movement of its plates. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

A stalker bodysuit worn by mercenaries in the Zone, painted in murky colours. The suit has a common presence amongst any mercenaries who have had experience in the Zone prior to becoming a part of the faction; nonetheless, its lack of resistance towards anything stronger than a pistol bullet makes it a seldom preferred alternative in comparison to other outfits. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

A suit used by mercenaries who often work in or near anomalous areas. It includes a protection system with a closed cycle, built-in suppression action anomalous fields. It provides good protection from bullet and shrapnel hit, but not enough for large-scale hostilities. Fully upgradeable and boasting two built-in artefact containers.

A suit of armour specifically made to withstand radiation hazards. It is composed of three elements: a reinforced jumpsuit, a heavy armoured vest, and a tactical helmet. The vest consists of several thick layers of Kevlar and can be reinforced with composite or titanium plates for increased protection. Comes with two built-in artefact containers.

A poor protective outfit contracted by government bureaucrats outsourcing to the lowest bidder. It slightly increases bullet, shrapnel, and bite protection. For soldiers serving in the Zone, it is as good as walking naked amidst rifle bullets and anomalies.

This item comprises military PS5 series body armour with beryllium coating modified for use in the Zone. Designed for assault operations in highly radioactive areas, it is ineffective in areas of high anomalous activity. The suit makes its way to stalkers through the military, who exchange it for loot. Does not come with an artefact container.

This modern military armoured suit is designed for assault operations in anomalous areas. Comprises a PSZ-12p heavy military armoured suit, built-in compensation suit, and an anomalous protection bodysuit. The armour provides excellent protection against bullet and fragmentation damage without greatly reducing the wearer's mobility. Does not come with an artefact container.

The Skat-9M bulletproof military suit is designed for assault operations in areas of anomalous activity. It includes a PSZ-12p heavy military bulletproof suit and an integrated compensation suit. Among its features are perfect protection from bullets, splinters, and anomalies alike, as well as its complete lack of any hindrance to the mobility of its wearer.
A lightweight suit used by the Monolith faction. It's based on the Wind of Freedom, albeit slightly modified to improve radiation resistance. Comes with an artefact container.

Standard body armour worn by the Monolith faction. Whilst many variants exist to improve their scientific or combat abilities, this model is the most common, being based on the Sunrise suit used by ordinary stalkers. Comes with two artefact containers.

The Monolith NBC suit is an advanced version of the standard Monolith suit. It comes with a GP-5 gas mask using a hose leading to a modern filter, in addition to improved sealing against electric hazards and extra carrying capacity.

The Monolith scientific suit includes a flak vest of unknown origin and also features unique modifications for greater resistance to radiation at the cost of being more vulnerable to psi-fields. The anomaly protection system has been upgraded to match the SEVA bodysuit. Comes with two built-in artefact containers.

A suit of armour specifically made to withstand radiation hazards. It is composed of three elements: a reinforced jumpsuit, a heavy armoured vest, and a tactical helmet. The vest consists of several thick layers of Kevlar and can be reinforced with composite or titanium plates for increased protection. Comes with two built-in artefact containers.

The leather jacket does not provide sufficient protection from the Zone's harsh conditions, considering it is simply a leather anorak. Typically, it is also worn with a backpack with extra straps across the chest. The leather offers little protection from gunfire or claws, and is absolutely useless against radiation or anomalies.

This DIY stalker bodysuit is a combination of twin-layered rubberised cloth with Plexiglas lining and built-in body armour. Despite the fact that the body armour is often strained by anything beyond even pistol bullets, the suit enjoys great popularity due to its low cost and modification potential. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

The NBC suit is an advanced version of the standard Sunrise suit. It comes standard with a GP-5 gas mask using a hose leading to a modern filter, in addition to improved sealing against electric hazards and extra carrying capacity. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

The uniform used by guards in and around the 100 Rads bar. Its design is based on the outfit used by mercenaries around the Zone. Due to a special treatment of the fabric, the armour has much strengthened stability to offset the physical movement of its plates. Its protective properties are slightly better then those of the PSZ-7 military bulletproof suits.

This suit, produced by one of Kiev's Defence Research Institutes, is a great alternative to home-made stalker suits. The anomaly and radiation protection system is second to none. Fully upgradeable and boasting two built-in artefact containers, this bodysuit is the equipment of choice for many experienced stalkers.

A modified SEVA suit with heavier emphasis on body armour. The anomaly protection features have slightly suffered due to this change of priorities. Fully upgradeable and boasting two built-in artefact containers.

A suit of armour specifically made to withstand radiation hazards. It is composed of three elements: a reinforced jumpsuit, a heavy armoured vest, and a tactical helmet. The vest consists of several thick layers of Kevlar and can be reinforced with composite or titanium plates for increased protection. Comes with a built-in artefact container.
A balaclava often used by stalkers to cover their identity. Protects the skin from radioactive dust.
A black beret awarded only to the best Ukrainian soldiers.

An aluminium/titanium helmet with a cloth exterior that comes with pockets for additional steel armour pieces and an armoured face mask. The Sphere M12 is normally used as part of a combination that includes PSZ series Spetsnaz body armour. Quite popular in the Zone thanks to its respirator and built-in first generation night vision device, as well as providing a large amount of head protection. Comes with electronics slots.

An ancient steel helmet attached to a respirator with ballistic goggles. A simple yet surprisingly effective combination. While it doesn't protect the whole head from bullets, the attached mask is adequate for the Zone's conditions.
A steel helmet riveted to a high quality respirator. Often paired with a CS-3a, it's capable of protecting the wearer from most anomalies. Comes with first generation night vision.
Combination of a relatively modern steel helmet and a reinforced respirator aimed at high bullet resistance and better sealing. Includes a first generation night vision.
A piece of cloth for covering one's mouth. Protects wearer from inhaling dust.

A desperately outdated steel army helmet without any additions. It provides no protection against anomalies or radiation, but can deflect bullets. The helmet has never been particularly popular in the Zone outside of brief armed conflicts between factions, although it sees a fair amount of use amongst members of Clear Sky, usually being fitted with a respirator for the faction's missions.

The M40 was the result of a programme in the 1980s to develop a successor to the M17-series protective masks. The M40 was to be a return to conventional gas mask design with an external side-mounted filter canister, rather than the internal cheek filters of the M17, which were awkward to change, especially in a contaminated environment. The M40 is favoured amongst many factions, particularly the mercenaries, as while it may lack strong protection against anomalies, it makes up for this by providing moderate bullet protection.

A light helmet with an airtight visor intended for protection against anomalies. Judging by the design, the helmet is made by the same Defence Research Institutes as the SEVA suit. Its intended use may very well be in combination with military suits for operations in highly anomalous areas.

A regular plastic and rubber gas mask, used for filtering air for radioactive particles and poisonous substances. Widely used by rookies and veterans of all factions due to its universal functionality. Does not provide any physical protection.

A regular plastic and rubber gas mask, used for filtering air for radioactive particles and poisonous substances. This older model is still used by rookies and veterans of all factions due to its universal functionality and cheap price. Does not provide any physical protection.

The GP-5 was designed to protect civilians of the Soviet Union from radioactive fallout during the Cold War and was manufactured from 1962 to 1989. This mask is a helmet-type mask which was made in both white and black rubber. The lenses of these masks are held in place by crimped metal rims, crimped onto the rubber of the mask. The bottom of the mask is made of metal, and in it is the 40mm filter input, and the inhale and exhale valves. The GP-5 is widely used by loners and bandits due to its availability and cheap price.

A regular plastic and rubber respirator, used to protect the wearer from inhaling harmful dusts, fumes, vapours, or gases. Widely used by rookies and veterans of all factions due to its universal functionality. Does not provide any physical protection.

A modern and modular army helmet with ballistic goggles and first generation night vision device. It provides no protection against anomalies or radiation, but can effectively deflect bullets. It's used by most military Spetsnaz soldiers.

A modern and modular army helmet with ballistic goggles and first generation night vision device. It provides no protection against anomalies or radiation, but can effectively deflect bullets. It's used by most military Spetsnaz soldiers. Equipped with respirator.

An element of combat equipment for special units of the MVD. Does not provide protection against anomalies or radiation, but is capable of deflecting a tangentially flown bullet. The helmet kit includes not only the helmet itself, but also anti-splinter goggles. He was in demand in the Zone only during the first clashes between factions.

A Western model of a tactical helmet. It is unknown how it ended up in the Zone. The helmet is designed to provide a squad leader with strategic superiority over the enemy via its many scanners and satellite communications devices, which have not been installed in this particular helmet. It comes with multi-layered Kevlar protection and armoured elements to protect vital electronic components, and also includes a respirator along with a first generation night vision device.

A dated aluminium/titanium helmet with an armour face mask and a cloth exterior that comes with pockets for additional steel armour pieces, providing the maximum head protection possible. The Tactical M12 is normally used as part of a combination that includes the PSZ series Spetsnaz body armour. It is quite rare in the Zone thanks to its limited production. It comes with a built-in first generation night vision device as well as electronics slots.
An ordinary waterproof backpack. It is popular among stalkers who make forays deep into the Zone.
An ordinary hiking duffel bag. It accommodates a lot, but it is very uncomfortable, which makes the body get tired quickly. It weighs almost nothing.
A frequent attribute of newcomers who drag them from outside the perimeter. There is practically no capacity, but you can comfortably place it on your back and not worry about the loss of swag.
A good sample in terms of price / quality ratio. It fits like a duffel bag, while it is relatively comfortable to carry on your back, although it is still far from ideal.

You don't often meet such people in the military themselves, and they don't need them. Basically, it is an attribute of various mercenaries and special purpose groups. Very expensive, but accommodates a lot while distributing the weight evenly over the body, from which you practically do not get tired.

A sample from the X-17 laboratory, on which an unknown symbolism is applied. It weighs quite a lot, but when you put it on, it doesn't matter. Allows you to easily carry a very large weight and not get tired. In addition, it has a positive effect on other characteristics of the body.
